text: The Rhineland massacres, or the German Crusade of 1096, were a series of massacres committed against Jews across the Holy Roman Empire (HRE) in 1096 AD. * * * * * * Cities where Jews were killed included Mainz and Speyer ‒ both centers of Jewish cultural life. Historians described the massacres as pogroms or genocidal massacres. ==Background== ===Jews in German lands=== Jews started living in German land in 321 AD under the Roman Empire. They formed the Yiddish-speaking Ashkenazi Jews (Hebrew: יהדות אשכנז) in the Middle Ages, * * * * * * * * who survived centuries of pogroms * * * * * * * * * * and expulsions into the 20th century. ===Systematic persecutions of Jews=== Under the Germanic Frankish Merovingian dynasty between the 5th and 8th century, Jews were banned from working as public servants. * * * * * A succession of ecumenical councils also banned Jews from socializing with Christians or observing the shabbat over the baseless fear that Judaism (the Jewish ethnoreligion) would influence Christians. Systematic persecutions of Jews intensified in the 11th century under the Capetian dynasty, when King Robert the Pious tried to kill all Jews who rejected Christian conversion. Jews across the German land were assaulted, tortured or burned at stakes. The persecutions coincided with the destruction of the original Church of the Holy Sepulchre in Jerusalem by the Fatimid Caliph Al-Hakim bi-Amr Allah in 1009, which was exploited by Benedictine monk Rodulfus Glaber to spread rumors about Jewish "involvement" in the destruction. These happened over the decades until the Rhineland massacres. ==Events== ===Massacres of Jews across the Holy Roman Empire=== The first massacres happened in Germanic Frankish land. Jewish historian Solomon bar Simson stated in the Hebrew Chronicles that Godfrey of Bouillon, one of the First Crusade's Catholic leaders, made their intention clear: A piece of anonymous work about the first massacres wrote: The massacres also came with looting of Jewish food and property by the Catholic Crusaders, with the Jews subject to attempts of forced conversion to Catholicism. Some Catholic Crusaders, including the Peter the Hermit, got what they wanted by extorting the Jews, some of whom barely survived the massacres by accepting forced baptism. ====Massacres of Jews in Regensburg==== Instances of forced baptism were reported in Regensburg, where some Catholic Crusaders forced the Jews into the river Danube for the baptism. Albert's narrative was shared by Jewish historian Solomon Bar Samson.Solomon Bar Samson, The Massacres of Jews, 49. Solomon Bar Samson wrote that the massacres happened before the Jews were even offered conversion. The local Bishop sent a messenger to the survivors, including Kalonymos ben Meshullam, and blamed them for their own suffering by repeating the claim that the Jews killed Jesus, asking them to convert to Christianity. Some Jews committed mass suicide instead of converting to Christianity, while some did so after forced baptism and the end of the massacres.
